fields.value: Census of Public and Private Juvenile Detention, Correctional, and Shelter Facilities, 1986-1987: [United States]

authorName.value: United States Department of Justice. Office of Justice Programs. Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention

authorAffiliation.value: United States Department of Justice. Office of Justice Programs. Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention

dsDescriptionValue.value: These data provide information on the population and characteristics of public and private juvenile facilities in operation in the United States on February 2, 1987. Annual data for the 1986 calendar year are included as well. Questions designed to categorize each facility were asked concerning the number of adults held, the juvenile majority's custodial authority, reason for custody, and access to the community, as well as the facility's security arrangements, capacity, age, plans for renovation, type of administration, and setting. Extensive data on the total juvenile residential population of each facility was also gathered. The total population is broken down by admission type, legal status, type of offense, race, and age. The collection also contains information on the population's movement and average length of stay, as well as each facility's average daily population, number and types of personnel, educational, treatment, and medical programs available, annual expenditures, court orders and consent decrees, and availability of juvenile records.

topicClassValue.value: ICPSR XVII.E. Social Institutions and Behavior, Crime and the Criminal Justice System

seriesName.value: Census of Public and Private Juvenile Detention, Correctional, and Shelter Facilities Series

value: Juveniles in public and private juvenile detention, correctional, and shelter facilities in operation in the United States on February 2, 1987.

fields.value:
Residential programs and group homes in operation on February 2, 1987, were included in the census if they housed three or more residents, if at least 50 percent of the residents were juveniles, and if accused or adjudicated delinquents and status offenders were at least 1 percent of their average daily population. In California, however, all California Youth Authority Facilities were included in the census. Juvenile facilities operated as part of adult jails were excluded, as were nonresidential facil
ities, facilities exclusively for drug or alcohol abusers or nonoffenders, and federal juvenile correctional facilities.
